Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Story: I was wiping the grease from my hands, mentally running through the checklist for next week’s machine servicing, when I heard the front door slam. My younger brother trudged in, his shoulders slumped, eyes red. I knew that look—something at school had gone wrong. He dropped his bag and sat at the kitchen table, silent, staring at nothing. I remembered Mom’s words: “You’re his big brother. He needs you, especially when things are tough.” I wanted to sit beside him, to listen, to be the support he expected. But my mind kept drifting to the machines at work. The shutdown was only days away, and if I didn’t finish prepping the parts tonight, the whole schedule could fall apart. My boss had made it clear: “No mistakes, no delays.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my brother’s need for comfort, my responsibility to the team. I stood in the hallway, torn, heart pounding, unsure which door to walk through first.
